bio_desc: Measures the average size of red blood cells. Used to classify types of anemia and assess bone marrow function. Abnormal values can indicate vitamin B12/folate deficiency, iron deficiency, or chronic disease.
Cumulative measure of cigarette smoking exposure (packs per day × years smoked). Higher values indicate greater risk for lung cancer, COPD, and cardiovascular disease.
Aminoacylase 1, an enzyme involved in amino acid metabolism, primarily in the liver and kidney. Important for breaking down certain peptides.
Enzyme found in liver, bile ducts, and bone. Elevated ALP can signal liver or bone disease; low levels are less common but may occur in rare genetic disorders.
Placental-type alkaline phosphatase, a protein mainly produced in the placenta. Outside pregnancy, elevated levels may be seen in some cancers.
Liver enzyme involved in amino acid metabolism. High ALT suggests liver cell injury from hepatitis, fatty liver, or toxins.
Main protein of LDL cholesterol particles. High ApoB means more LDL particles, increasing risk for atherosclerosis and heart disease.
Apolipoprotein E, a protein involved in cholesterol transport and metabolism. Certain genetic variants increase risk for Alzheimer's and cardiovascular disease.
Enzyme in liver, heart, and muscle. Elevated AST can indicate liver damage, muscle injury, or heart problems.
Ratio of two liver enzymes. Helps distinguish between different types of liver disease, such as alcoholic vs. non-alcoholic liver injury.
Essential amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, valine) important for muscle metabolism. Elevated BCAAs are linked to insulin resistance and metabolic disorders.
Self-reported frequency of eating beef. High intake is associated with increased risk of heart disease and certain cancers.
Self-reported frequency of drinking beer or cider. Alcohol intake affects liver, heart, and cancer risk.
Weight-to-height ratio (kg/m²). Used to classify underweight, normal weight, overweight, or obesity. High BMI is linked to diabetes, heart disease, and some cancers.
Proportion of body weight that is fat tissue. High body fat increases risk for metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease.
Provides calcium, essential for bone health, muscle contraction, and nerve function. Used to prevent osteoporosis and support bone strength.
Self-reported intake of champagne or white wine. Moderate consumption may have some heart benefits; excess increases risk for liver disease and cancer.
Frequency of cheese intake. Cheese is rich in protein and calcium but can be high in saturated fat and salt.
Waste product from muscle metabolism, filtered by kidneys. Blood levels assess kidney function; high levels may indicate kidney dysfunction.
Protein produced by the liver in response to inflammation. High CRP signals acute or chronic inflammation and is a risk marker for heart disease.
Chemokine protein involved in immune cell recruitment and mucosal immunity. Its precise disease role is under study.
Protein produced by all nucleated cells, filtered by kidneys. Sensitive marker of kidney function, often more reliable than creatinine.
Ectodysplasin A2 receptor, a protein involved in cell signaling and development.
Ephrin-A4, a protein involved in cell signaling, especially in nervous system development.
Type of white blood cell involved in allergic reactions and fighting parasites. High counts may indicate allergies, asthma, or parasitic infection.
Supplement containing gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), an omega-6 fatty acid. Used for skin health, PMS, and inflammation, though evidence is mixed.
Provides omega-3 fatty acids (EPA, DHA) for heart, brain, and eye health. May reduce triglycerides and inflammation.
Provides vitamin B9, essential for DNA synthesis and cell division. Important in pregnancy to prevent birth defects; supports heart health.
Contains compounds like allicin. Used for cardiovascular health, blood pressure control, and immune support. May have mild cholesterol-lowering effects.
Growth Differentiation Factor 15, a protein regulating inflammation and cellular stress. Elevated in cancer, heart disease, and metabolic disorders.
Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein, found in brain and spinal cord. Marker for brain injury and neurological disease.
Enzyme involved in liver function and bile production. High GGT can indicate liver disease, bile duct problems, or alcohol use.
Supports joint health and may reduce osteoarthritis symptoms. Involved in cartilage formation and repair.
Measures blood sugar level. Used to diagnose and monitor diabetes. Regulated by insulin, produced/processed by pancreas and liver.
Amino acid important for immune function, gut health, and muscle recovery. Used as a supplement in clinical and athletic settings.
Non-essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis, neurotransmission, and as a precursor for other biomolecules.
Assesses muscular strength using a hand dynamometer. Lower grip strength is linked to higher risk of disability, frailty, and mortality.
Good cholesterol that helps remove excess cholesterol from blood. High HDL is protective against heart disease.
Percentage of blood volume made up by red blood cells. Low values suggest anemia; high values may indicate dehydration or polycythemia.
Protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. Low hemoglobin indicates anemia; high levels may occur in certain diseases.
Reflects average blood glucose over 2–3 months. Used to diagnose and monitor diabetes.
Essential amino acid involved in growth, tissue repair, and production of histamine, an immune mediator.
Insulin-like Growth Factor 1, a hormone produced mainly in the liver. Promotes growth in childhood and has anabolic effects in adults.
Insulin-like Growth Factor Binding Protein 4, regulates IGF1 and IGF2 activity, modulating growth and metabolism.
Immunoglobulin Superfamily Member 3, involved in cell adhesion and immune response.
Immunoglobulin Superfamily Member 9, involved in cell-cell interactions, especially in the nervous system.
Provides iron, necessary for making hemoglobin and supporting oxygen transport in blood. Used to treat or prevent iron-deficiency anemia.
Keratin 18, a structural protein in epithelial cells. Marker of cell death in liver disease and some cancers.
Ratio of LDL cholesterol to apolipoprotein B. Helps assess number and size of LDL particles for cardiovascular risk.
Bad cholesterol that can build up in arteries, increasing risk for heart disease and stroke.
Essential branched-chain amino acid important for protein synthesis, muscle repair, and energy production.
Lipoprotein particle similar to LDL with an added protein. High levels are a genetic risk factor for cardiovascular disease.
Proportion of white blood cells that are lymphocytes, key to immune defense. Abnormal values may indicate infection, immune disorders, or blood cancers.
Absolute number of lymphocytes in blood, reflecting immune system activity.
White blood cell type involved in immune defense and inflammation. High counts can indicate infection or chronic inflammation.
Healthy fats found in olive oil, nuts, and avocados. Support heart health by improving cholesterol and reducing inflammation.
Contains a blend of essential vitamins and minerals. Used to prevent or address nutritional deficiencies and support general health.
Neurofilament Light Chain, a protein in nerve cells. Marker for nerve damage or neurodegenerative disease.
Most abundant white blood cell type, crucial for fighting bacterial infections. High counts suggest infection or inflammation.
Frequency of eating fatty fish like salmon, mackerel, or sardines. Rich in omega-3s, supporting heart and brain health.
Essential polyunsaturated fats found in fish and some plants. Reduce inflammation, support heart and brain health, lower risk of chronic diseases.
Essential fats found in vegetable oils and nuts. Important for cell structure and metabolism; excess intake relative to omega-3s may promote inflammation.
Balance of omega-6 to omega-3 fatty acids in the diet. High ratio is linked to increased inflammation and risk of chronic disease.
Essential amino acid needed for protein synthesis and neurotransmitter production. High levels can be harmful in phenylketonuria (PKU).
Plasminogen Activator, Urokinase Receptor, involved in breaking down blood clots and tissue remodeling.
Fats found in fish, nuts, and seeds. Includes omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, essential for health and inflammation regulation.
Self-reported frequency of eating chicken or turkey. Poultry is a source of lean protein and other nutrients.
Number of red blood cells in blood. Low RBC can indicate anemia; high levels may occur in dehydration or certain diseases.
Measures variation in red blood cell size. High RDW can indicate mixed types of anemia or other blood disorders.
Frequency of drinking red wine. Moderate intake may have heart benefits; excess increases risk for liver disease and cancer.
Number of heartbeats per minute at rest. Lower rates generally indicate better cardiovascular fitness.
Frequency of adding salt to meals. High salt intake is linked to high blood pressure and increased risk of heart disease and stroke.
Fats found in animal products and some plant oils. High intake is associated with increased cholesterol and heart disease risk.
Provides selenium, a trace mineral important for antioxidant defense, thyroid function, and immune health.
Protein that binds sex hormones (testosterone, estrogen) in blood, regulating their availability to tissues.
Intake of distilled alcoholic beverages (vodka, gin, whiskey, etc.). High consumption increases risk for liver disease, cancer, and other health problems.
Top number in a blood pressure reading, representing pressure in arteries when the heart beats. High levels are a major risk factor for heart disease and stroke.
Main male sex hormone, important for muscle mass, bone density, and reproductive health. Abnormal levels affect mood, energy, and sexual function.
Tumor Necrosis Factor Receptor Superfamily Member 10B, a protein involved in cell death signaling.
Sum of all fatty acids in the blood, reflecting dietary fat intake and metabolism.
Main form of fat in the blood. High levels are linked to increased risk of heart disease and pancreatitis.
Amino acid used to make proteins and neurotransmitters like dopamine and norepinephrine.
Waste product from breakdown of purines in food. High levels can cause gout and kidney stones.
Waste product formed from protein breakdown, filtered by kidneys. High levels can indicate kidney dysfunction.
Provides vitamin A, essential for vision, immune function, and skin health.
Contains a mix of B vitamins (B1, B2, B3, B6, B12, etc.), important for energy metabolism, nerve function, and red blood cell formation.
Provides vitamin C, an antioxidant important for immune health, collagen formation, and iron absorption.
Fat-soluble vitamin produced in skin with sun exposure and obtained from diet. Essential for bone health, immune function, and reducing risk of chronic diseases.
Supplement form of vitamin D, used to maintain healthy bones and immune system, especially in people with low sun exposure or absorption issues.
Provides vitamin E, an antioxidant that protects cells from damage and supports immune health.
Supplement providing a mix of essential vitamins for overall health and to prevent deficiencies.
Measurement around the abdomen. High values indicate abdominal obesity, a strong risk factor for metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and heart disease.
Self-reported amount of water consumed daily. Adequate hydration is essential for all bodily functions, including temperature regulation, kidney health, and cognitive performance.
Total number of white blood cells in blood, reflecting immune system activity and response to infection or inflammation.
WAP Four-Disulfide Core Domain Protein 2 (HE4), used as a biomarker for ovarian cancer and other conditions.
Provides zinc, an essential mineral for immune function, wound healing, and DNA synthesis.
